intro: Glyceria lithuanica f. violacea, commonly known as the violet-flowered glyceria, is a rare subspecies native to parts of Eastern Europe. It is a perennial grass-like plant belonging to the Poaceae family, characterized by its slender, grassy stems and striking violet-blue flower spikes. The plant typically grows in moist, nutrient-rich soils along riverbanks and wetlands. Its unique floral coloration distinguishes it from other members of the species, making it a notable subject in botanical studies. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant plant.
